text: We can't even get the doses we have out to people, what sense does doubling the supply make?

elements.text: We can't even get the doses we have out to people, what sense does doubling the supply make?

text: None. None of it makes any sense.

elements.text: None. None of it makes any sense.

text: Talk of a single dose or halving the dose is also just crazy. We don't have sufficient data to show that actually should work.

elements.text: Talk of a single dose or halving the dose is also just crazy. We don't have sufficient data to show that actually should work.

text: Talk to going to 50 micrograms based on this is dangerous:

text: Notice that they never designed a study to test if 50 micrograms is effective.

text: They only tested if 100 micrograms is effective.

text: The twitter thread I linked to above has a whole list of different references for what's known, and yeah... people are making huge errors of extrapolation

text: I really wish we'd spent 5% of the vaccine development budget planning for this shit

elements.text: I really wish we'd spent 5% of the vaccine development budget planning for this shit

text:
I think the vaccine developers did exactly what they should have done. They focused on the most likely dose to work, and then showed that it was effective. That was the fastest path.

What some people are trying to do is optimize delivery without testing if the optimizations may compromise effectiveness.

elements.text:
I think the vaccine developers did exactly what they should have done. They focused on the most likely dose to work, and then showed that it was effective. That was the fastest path.

What some people are trying to do is optimize delivery without testing if the optimizations may compromise effectiveness.

text:
The analogy to software development is 1) we first write the tests (ideally) 2) then get the code to work and pass the tests. At that point we make a release.

After the initial release, we may try to optimize. But before we release again, we definitely need to run the tests to make sure our optimizations did not break anything.

What they are trying to do is optimize without testing. That's crazy.

elements.text:

text: The ideas are pretty good. They are even supported by some evidence. However, they really need to be tested so we can figure out if the ideas actually work.

elements.text: The ideas are pretty good. They are even supported by some evidence. However, they really need to be tested so we can figure out if the ideas actually work.

text: That's kind of the problem, testing anything in this business takes months, and we don't have months
